documents.doc_type: Supreme Court Order - Divorce and Parenting
documents.title: Chen v. Chen - Final Order
documents.content:
IN THE SUPREME COURT OF BRITISH COLUMBIA

BETWEEN:
MICHAEL CHEN
Claimant
AND:
SARAH CHEN
Respondent

Before: The Honourable Justice R. Thompson
Date: June 15, 2024
Docket: E-224156
Registry: Vancouver

FINAL ORDER

THIS COURT ORDERS that:

DIVORCE
1. A divorce is granted under the Divorce Act (Canada) effective 31 days from the date of this order.

GUARDIANSHIP AND PARENTING ARRANGEMENTS
2. Both parties are guardians of the children of the marriage, namely:
   (a) Emma Chen, born March 12, 2016; and
   (b) Lucas Chen, born September 3, 2019.

3. The children shall reside primarily with the Respondent mother.

4. The Claimant father shall have parenting time as follows:
   (a) Every other weekend from Friday at 5:00 p.m. to Sunday at 6:00 p.m.;
   (b) Every Wednesday from 4:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.;
   (c) Two consecutive weeks during summer vacation, with dates to be confirmed by May 1 each year;
   (d) Alternating statutory holidays and school breaks as set out in Schedule A attached.

5. Neither party shall relocate the children's habitual residence more than 50 kilometers from their current residence at 2847 Oak Street, Vancouver, BC without written consent of the other party or court order.

CHILD SUPPORT
6. The Claimant shall pay to the Respondent child support in the amount of $2,340 per month for both children, based on his annual income of $145,000, commencing July 1, 2024.

7. The parties shall share section 7 expenses proportionally based on their respective incomes (Claimant 62%, Respondent 38%), including:
   (a) Childcare expenses;
   (b) Medical and dental expenses not covered by insurance;
   (c) Extracurricular activities agreed upon by both parties.

SPOUSAL SUPPORT
8. The Claimant shall pay to the Respondent spousal support in the amount of $1,800 per month for a period of 7 years, commencing July 1, 2024, subject to material change in circumstances.

9. The Respondent's entitlement to spousal support is compensatory in nature, recognizing her career sacrifices during the 12-year marriage to care for the children.

PROPERTY DIVISION
10. The family residence at 2847 Oak Street, Vancouver, BC shall be sold and the net proceeds divided equally between the parties.

11. The Claimant shall retain his RRSP holdings valued at $186,000 and shall pay an equalization payment of $47,500 to the Respondent within 90 days of this order.

12. Each party shall retain the motor vehicle currently registered in their name.

13. The Respondent shall retain the contents of the family home, except for items listed in Schedule B attached.

COSTS
14. Each party shall bear their own costs.

_______________________
The Honourable Justice R. Thompson

documents.title: Patel-Singh Separation Agreement
Affidavit of Rebecca Foster
documents.content:
SUPREME COURT OF BRITISH COLUMBIA

BETWEEN:
REBECCA FOSTER
Claimant
AND:
DAVID FOSTER
Respondent

File No: E-231456
Registry: Kelowna

AFFIDAVIT #1 OF REBECCA FOSTER

I, REBECCA FOSTER, of Kelowna, British Columbia, MAKE OATH AND SAY:

1. I am the Claimant in this proceeding and have personal knowledge of the matters deposed to in this Affidavit, except where stated to be based on information and belief.

BACKGROUND

2. The Respondent David Foster ("David") and I were married on June 18, 2016 in Kelowna, BC. We separated on August 5, 2024.

3. We have one child together, Olivia Foster, born April 22, 2021. Olivia is currently 3 years old.

4. During our marriage, I was Olivia's primary caregiver. I reduced my work hours to part-time (20 hours per week) after Olivia was born to care for her. David continued working full-time as a commercial pilot for WestJet.

CURRENT CIRCUMSTANCES

5. Since our separation, David has been exercising parenting time every other weekend from Saturday morning to Sunday evening. This arrangement was informal and not pursuant to any court order.

6. On October 15, 2024, David informed me that he intends to seek a 50/50 parenting arrangement. I am opposed to this proposal for the following reasons:

   (a) Olivia has been in my primary care since birth. A sudden change to equal parenting time would be disruptive to her routine and emotional wellbeing.

   (b) David's work schedule as a pilot is unpredictable. He is frequently away for 3-5 days at a time. Attached as Exhibit "A" is a copy of his flight schedule for September and October 2024, showing 14 days away in September and 12 days away in October.

   (c) David has not demonstrated he can manage Olivia's care independently. On September 28, 2024, when David had Olivia for the weekend, he left her with his mother without informing me. I only discovered this when I called to speak with Olivia.

   (d) David has not attended any of Olivia's medical appointments since our separation. Attached as Exhibit "B" is a list of appointments I have taken Olivia to since August 2024.

OLIVIA'S BEST INTERESTS

7. I believe Olivia's best interests are served by maintaining the current arrangement with me as her primary caregiver. I am seeking the following:

   (a) An order that Olivia's primary residence be with me;

   (b) David to have parenting time every other weekend from Friday at 5:00 p.m. to Sunday at 5:00 p.m., and one evening per week;

   (c) A gradual increase in David's parenting time over the next 12 months as Olivia adjusts, with a review at that time;

   (d) That David provide his work schedule to me at least 14 days in advance so that parenting time can be arranged accordingly.

CHILD SUPPORT

8. David's annual income is approximately $125,000 based on his 2023 tax return. I am seeking child support in accordance with the Federal Child Support Guidelines.

9. My current annual income is $38,000 from my part-time position as a dental hygienist.

URGENT CIRCUMSTANCES

10. On October 28, 2024, David sent me a text message stating that he plans to keep Olivia for "as long as I want" during his next scheduled parenting time. A copy of this text message is attached as Exhibit "C".

11. I am concerned that David may attempt to retain Olivia beyond his scheduled parenting time. I am seeking an interim order to prevent this.

SWORN BEFORE ME at Kelowna,
British Columbia, on November 2, 2024

_________________________
A Commissioner for Taking Affidavits
for British Columbia

_________________________
REBECCA FOSTER

documents.doc_type: Provincial Court Order - Child Support Variation
documents.title: Williams v. Thompson - Variation Order
documents.content:
PROVINCIAL COURT OF BRITISH COLUMBIA
FAMILY COURT

BETWEEN:
MARCUS WILLIAMS
Applicant
AND:
JENNIFER THOMPSON
Respondent

Before: Judge K. Sandhu
Date: August 22, 2024
File No: FN-19-4523
Registry: New Westminster

REASONS FOR JUDGMENT AND ORDER

INTRODUCTION

[1] The Applicant, Marcus Williams, seeks to vary a child support order dated March 15, 2021. He claims a material change in circumstances due to job loss and subsequent re-employment at a lower income.

[2] The Respondent, Jennifer Thompson, opposes the variation and seeks retroactive child support for alleged underpayment.

BACKGROUND

[3] The parties separated in January 2021. They have two children: Jayden, born 2014, and Maya, born 2017.

[4] The March 2021 order required Mr. Williams to pay child support of $1,650 per month based on his then-income of $98,000 annually.

[5] Mr. Williams was laid off from his position as an IT manager in February 2023. He received severance of $45,000. He was unemployed for 8 months before finding new employment as a technical support specialist at an annual salary of $62,000.

ANALYSIS

Material Change in Circumstances

[6] Under section 152 of the Family Law Act, a court may vary a child support order if there has been a change in circumstances since the order was made.

[7] I find that Mr. Williams' job loss and re-employment at a significantly lower salary constitutes a material change in circumstances. His income has decreased by approximately 37%.

[8] However, I must also consider whether this change was voluntary or involuntary. Based on the evidence, including the Record of Employment attached as Exhibit 3, I find that Mr. Williams' layoff was involuntary and resulted from company downsizing.

[9] Ms. Thompson argues that Mr. Williams is intentionally underemployed. She points to his qualifications and previous salary. However, Mr. Williams has provided evidence of 47 job applications submitted between March and October 2023. I find that he made reasonable efforts to find comparable employment.

Income Determination

[10] Mr. Williams' current T4 and pay stubs show an annual income of $62,000. I am satisfied this represents his actual income.

[11] Regarding the $45,000 severance payment, I find that this was a one-time payment that should be prorated over a reasonable period. Given the 8-month unemployment period, I will add $5,625 per month to his income for those months.

[12] For the period October 2023 onwards, I accept Mr. Williams' income as $62,000 annually.

Retroactive Support

[13] Ms. Thompson seeks retroactive support claiming Mr. Williams underpaid by approximately $200 per month from January 2022 to February 2023 when his income exceeded $98,000.

[14] She has provided copies of Mr. Williams' 2021 and 2022 tax returns showing income of $104,000 and $108,000 respectively.

[15] Applying the Guidelines table amount, child support should have been $1,740 per month at $104,000 income and $1,810 per month at $108,000 income.

[16] I find that Mr. Williams underpaid by:
    - 2022: ($1,740 - $1,650) × 12 = $1,080
    - January-February 2023: ($1,810 - $1,650) × 2 = $320
    - Total retroactive amount: $1,400

ORDER

[17] THIS COURT ORDERS THAT:

1. The child support order dated March 15, 2021 is varied effective October 1, 2023.

2. Commencing October 1, 2023, Mr. Williams shall pay child support to Ms. Thompson in the amount of $982 per month for the two children, based on his annual income of $62,000.

3. Mr. Williams shall pay retroactive child support of $1,400 to Ms. Thompson within 60 days of this order.

4. The parties shall exchange income tax returns and notices of assessment by June 15 of each year.

5. Either party may apply to vary this order upon a material change in circumstances.

6. No order as to costs.

_______________________
Judge K. Sandhu
Provincial Court of British Columbia

SUPREME COURT OF BRITISH COLUMBIA
FINANCIAL STATEMENT (FORM F8)

File No: E-224156

BETWEEN:
MICHAEL CHEN
Claimant
AND:
SARAH CHEN

FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF MICHAEL CHEN

I, MICHAEL CHEN, of Vancouver, British Columbia, MAKE OATH AND SAY:

PART 1 - INCOME INFORMATION

1. Employment Income
   Current Employer: TechVentures Inc.
   Position: Software Engineering Manager
   Gross Annual Salary: $145,000
   Net Monthly Income: $8,420
   Employment Start Date: March 1, 2019

2. Other Income
   Stock options (vested): approximately $12,000 annually
   Side consulting: approximately $8,000 annually

3. Total Line 15000 Income (2023 Tax Return): $162,340

PART 2 - MONTHLY EXPENSES

4. Housing
   Rent (current apartment): $2,200
   Utilities: $180
   Internet/Phone: $150
   Renter's Insurance: $45

5. Transportation
   Car payment (2021 Toyota RAV4): $520
   Insurance: $185
   Fuel: $280
   Parking: $150
   Maintenance: $75

6. Personal
   Food and household: $750
   Clothing: $150
   Personal care: $60
   Entertainment: $200
   Gym membership: $65

7. Children's Expenses (during parenting time)
   Food and activities: $400
   Children's clothing contribution: $150
   School supplies: $50

8. Debt Payments
   Student loan ($18,000 balance): $350/month
   Credit card: $200/month average

9. Other
   Life insurance premium: $125
   RRSP contribution: $750
   Professional development: $100

Total Monthly Expenses: $7,135

PART 3 - ASSETS

10. Real Property
    50% interest in family home at 2847 Oak Street, Vancouver
    Fair Market Value (total): $1,850,000
    Mortgage Balance: $620,000
    My 50% Equity: $615,000

11. Bank Accounts
    RBC Chequing: $12,340
    RBC Savings: $28,500
    Wealthsimple Investment Account: $45,670

12. Registered Accounts
    RRSP (RBC Direct Investing): $186,000
    TFSA (Wealthsimple): $42,000

13. Vehicles
    2021 Toyota RAV4: $32,000 (est. value), loan balance $18,500

14. Pensions
    Defined Contribution Pension (employer): $78,000 current value
    Vested and portable

15. Other Assets
    Stock options (unvested): $35,000 (estimated)
    Electronics and personal items: $8,000

PART 4 - LIABILITIES

16. Debts
    Mortgage (50% of $620,000): $310,000
    Car loan: $18,500
    Student loan: $18,000
    Credit cards: $4,200
    Total Liabilities: $350,700

PART 5 - NET WORTH SUMMARY

17. Total Assets: $1,082,510
    Total Liabilities: $350,700
    Net Worth: $731,810

PART 6 - PROPOSED SUPPORT

18. I acknowledge the Federal Child Support Guidelines table amount for two children at my income level of $145,000 is $2,340 per month.

19. I am prepared to pay child support as per the Guidelines.

20. Regarding spousal support, I propose $1,500 per month for a period of 5 years, based on the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines mid-range.

SWORN BEFORE ME at Vancouver,
British Columbia, on May 1, 2024

_________________________
A Commissioner for Taking Affidavits

_________________________
MICHAEL CHEN

qa_pairs.question: What is the monthly child support amount ordered in the Chen divorce, and what income is it based on?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The court ordered child support of $2,340 per month for both children, based on the Claimant's (Michael Chen's) annual income of $145,000.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: The Claimant shall pay to the Respondent child support in the amount of $2,340 per month for both children, based on his annual income of $145,000, commencing July 1, 2024.

qa_pairs.question: How are section 7 expenses to be shared between the Chen parties, and what expenses are included?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Section 7 expenses are to be shared proportionally based on income: the Claimant pays 62% and the Respondent pays 38%. The included expenses are: childcare expenses, medical and dental expenses not covered by insurance, and extracurricular activities agreed upon by both parties.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: The parties shall share section 7 expenses proportionally based on their respective incomes (Claimant 62%, Respondent 38%), including: (a) Childcare expenses; (b) Medical and dental expenses not covered by insurance; (c) Extracurricular activities agreed upon by both parties.

qa_pairs.question: When does the Chen spousal support obligation end?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The spousal support obligation runs for 7 years from July 1, 2024, so it would end on July 1, 2031, subject to material change in circumstances.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: The Claimant shall pay to the Respondent spousal support in the amount of $1,800 per month for a period of 7 years, commencing July 1, 2024, subject to material change in circumstances.

qa_pairs.question: What is the basis for Sarah Chen's spousal support entitlement according to the court order?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The Respondent's entitlement to spousal support is compensatory in nature, recognizing her career sacrifices during the 12-year marriage to care for the children.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: The Respondent's entitlement to spousal support is compensatory in nature, recognizing her career sacrifices during the 12-year marriage to care for the children.

qa_pairs.question: What is the relocation restriction distance in the Chen order, and from what address?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Neither party may relocate the children more than 50 kilometers from their current residence at 2847 Oak Street, Vancouver, BC without written consent or court order.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Neither party shall relocate the children's habitual residence more than 50 kilometers from their current residence at 2847 Oak Street, Vancouver, BC without written consent of the other party or court order.

qa_pairs.question: What is James Morrison's net worth according to his financial statement?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: James Morrison's net worth is $824,140, calculated as total assets of $1,331,540 minus total liabilities of $507,400.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet:
Total Assets: $1,331,540
Total Liabilities: $507,400
Net Worth: $824,140

qa_pairs.question: What is the equity in James Morrison's investment property, and what percentage of his net worth does it represent?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The equity in the investment condo at 889 Pacific Blvd is $273,000 ($685,000 fair market value minus $412,000 mortgage). This represents approximately 33.1% of his net worth of $824,140.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet:
Investment condo at 1420-889 Pacific Blvd, Vancouver
Fair Market Value: $685,000
Mortgage Balance: $412,000
Equity: $273,000

qa_pairs.question: What is James Morrison's total annual income from all sources according to his 2023 tax return?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: According to James Morrison's 2023 tax return, his total Line 15000 income was $189,450.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Total Line 15000 Income (2023 Tax Return): $189,450

qa_pairs.question: Is James Morrison's monthly income sufficient to cover his expenses based on his financial statement?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Yes, his net monthly income of $9,847 exceeds his total monthly expenses of $8,774, leaving approximately $1,073 surplus per month.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Net Monthly Income: $9,847... Total Monthly Expenses: $8,774

qa_pairs.question: What is the child support amount in the Patel-Singh agreement, and why is it lower than the full table amount?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The child support is $847 per month as a set-off amount. It's calculated this way because Rajesh has shared parenting time exceeding 40%, so support is calculated under section 9 of the Federal Child Support Guidelines rather than the standard table amount.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Based on shared parenting time exceeding 40%, child support shall be calculated under section 9 of the Federal Child Support Guidelines. The set-off amount payable by Rajesh to Priya is $847 per month.

qa_pairs.question: What are the terms of Priya Singh's spousal support waiver in the separation agreement?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Priya waives any claim to spousal support, acknowledging that: she is self-sufficient with stable employment, she has received independent legal advice regarding the waiver, and the waiver is final and not subject to variation. Rajesh also waives any claim to spousal support from Priya.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Priya waives any claim to spousal support, acknowledging that: (a) She is self-sufficient with stable employment; (b) She has received independent legal advice regarding this waiver; (c) This waiver is final and not subject to variation.

qa_pairs.question: How much must Rajesh transfer from his RRSP to Priya, and how were the RRSP equalization amounts calculated?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Rajesh must transfer $46,000 from his RRSP to Priya's RRSP. The calculation: Rajesh has $134,000 in RRSPs and Priya has $42,000, for a total of $176,000. Equal division would give each $88,000. Priya needs $46,000 more ($88,000 - $42,000) to reach equal value.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Rajesh holds RRSPs valued at $134,000; Priya holds RRSPs valued at $42,000; Rajesh shall transfer $46,000 from his RRSP to Priya's RRSP within 60 days of this Agreement

qa_pairs.question: What percentage of section 7 expenses does each party pay in the Patel-Singh agreement, and what is Rajesh's share of the daycare costs?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Rajesh pays 68% and Priya pays 32% of section 7 expenses based on their incomes. With daycare at $1,450 per month, Rajesh's share would be $986 per month (68% of $1,450).
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: The Parties shall share special or extraordinary expenses in proportion to their incomes (Rajesh 68%, Priya 32%), including: (a) Daycare for Dev: currently $1,450/month

qa_pairs.question: How is pension division handled in the Patel-Singh agreement?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Priya is entitled to 50% of the pension benefits Rajesh accrued during the marriage (August 22, 2015 to January 15, 2024). The division will be effected by a separate pension division order under the Pension Benefits Standards Act. The pension is Rajesh's defined benefit pension with BC Hydro.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Rajesh's defined benefit pension with BC Hydro shall be divided as follows: (a) Priya is entitled to 50% of the pension benefits accrued during the marriage (August 22, 2015 to January 15, 2024); (b) Division shall be effected by a separate pension division order under the Pension Benefits Standards Act.

qa_pairs.question: What is the relocation restriction in the Patel-Singh agreement?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Neither party shall relocate the children more than 75 kilometers from their current school without 60 days written notice and the other party's consent or a court order.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Neither Party shall relocate the Children more than 75 kilometers from their current school without 60 days written notice and the other Party's consent or court order.

qa_pairs.question: What specific concerns does Rebecca Foster raise about David's ability to care for Olivia?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Rebecca raises the following concerns: (1) A sudden change to 50/50 would disrupt Olivia's routine as Rebecca has been primary caregiver since birth; (2) David's work schedule as a pilot is unpredictable with 14 days away in September and 12 days in October; (3) David left Olivia with his mother without informing Rebecca on September 28, 2024; (4) David has not attended any of Olivia's medical appointments since separation.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: David's work schedule as a pilot is unpredictable. He is frequently away for 3-5 days at a time... On September 28, 2024, when David had Olivia for the weekend, he left her with his mother without informing me... David has not attended any of Olivia's medical appointments since our separation.

qa_pairs.question: What parenting arrangement is Rebecca Foster seeking for Olivia?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: Rebecca is seeking: (1) An order that Olivia's primary residence be with her; (2) David to have parenting time every other weekend Friday 5pm to Sunday 5pm and one evening per week; (3) A gradual increase in David's parenting time over 12 months with a review at that time; (4) David must provide his work schedule at least 14 days in advance.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: I am seeking the following: (a) An order that Olivia's primary residence be with me; (b) David to have parenting time every other weekend from Friday at 5:00 p.m. to Sunday at 5:00 p.m., and one evening per week; (c) A gradual increase in David's parenting time over the next 12 months as Olivia adjusts, with a review at that time; (d) That David provide his work schedule to me at least 14 days in advance

qa_pairs.question: What are the income figures for the Foster parties?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: David Foster's annual income is approximately $125,000 based on his 2023 tax return. Rebecca Foster's current annual income is $38,000 from her part-time position as a dental hygienist.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: David's annual income is approximately $125,000 based on his 2023 tax return... My current annual income is $38,000 from my part-time position as a dental hygienist.

qa_pairs.question: What urgent circumstances led Rebecca Foster to seek an interim order?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: On October 28, 2024, David sent Rebecca a text message stating he plans to keep Olivia for 'as long as I want' during his next scheduled parenting time. Rebecca is concerned David may attempt to retain Olivia beyond his scheduled time and seeks an interim order to prevent this.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: On October 28, 2024, David sent me a text message stating that he plans to keep Olivia for 'as long as I want' during his next scheduled parenting time... I am concerned that David may attempt to retain Olivia beyond his scheduled parenting time.

qa_pairs.question: Why did the court find that Marcus Williams was not intentionally underemployed?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The court found the layoff was involuntary based on the Record of Employment showing company downsizing. Additionally, Marcus provided evidence of 47 job applications between March and October 2023, demonstrating he made reasonable efforts to find comparable employment.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Based on the evidence, including the Record of Employment attached as Exhibit 3, I find that Mr. Williams' layoff was involuntary and resulted from company downsizing... Mr. Williams has provided evidence of 47 job applications submitted between March and October 2023. I find that he made reasonable efforts to find comparable employment.

qa_pairs.question: How did the court calculate the retroactive child support owed by Marcus Williams?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The court found Marcus underpaid based on his actual income being higher than the $98,000 used in the original order. For 2022, at $104,000 income, support should have been $1,740/month not $1,650, resulting in $1,080 underpayment ($90 × 12). For January-February 2023, at $108,000 income, support should have been $1,810/month, resulting in $320 underpayment ($160 × 2). Total retroactive amount: $1,400.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: I find that Mr. Williams underpaid by: 2022: ($1,740 - $1,650) × 12 = $1,080; January-February 2023: ($1,810 - $1,650) × 2 = $320; Total retroactive amount: $1,400

qa_pairs.question: How did the court treat Marcus Williams' severance payment for income calculation?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The court found the $45,000 severance was a one-time payment that should be prorated over the 8-month unemployment period. This added $5,625 per month to his income during those months ($45,000 ÷ 8 = $5,625).
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Regarding the $45,000 severance payment, I find that this was a one-time payment that should be prorated over a reasonable period. Given the 8-month unemployment period, I will add $5,625 per month to his income for those months.

qa_pairs.question: What is the new child support amount ordered for Marcus Williams and when does it take effect?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The new child support amount is $982 per month for two children, based on Marcus's annual income of $62,000, effective October 1, 2023.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Commencing October 1, 2023, Mr. Williams shall pay child support to Ms. Thompson in the amount of $982 per month for the two children, based on his annual income of $62,000.

qa_pairs.question: What was the percentage decrease in Marcus Williams' child support obligation after the variation?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The child support decreased from $1,650 per month to $982 per month, a reduction of $668 per month or approximately 40.5% decrease.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: The March 2021 order required Mr. Williams to pay child support of $1,650 per month... Mr. Williams shall pay child support to Ms. Thompson in the amount of $982 per month

qa_pairs.question: Compare the relocation restrictions in the Chen court order versus the Patel-Singh separation agreement. Which is more restrictive?
qa_pairs.ground_truth_answer: The Chen order restricts relocation to 50 kilometers from their current residence (2847 Oak Street, Vancouver) and requires written consent or court order. The Patel-Singh agreement restricts relocation to 75 kilometers from the children's current school and requires 60 days written notice plus consent or court order. The Chen order is more restrictive with a shorter distance (50km vs 75km), though the Patel-Singh agreement has an additional notice requirement of 60 days.
qa_pairs.relevant_snippet: Chen: 'relocate the children's habitual residence more than 50 kilometers from their current residence at 2847 Oak Street, Vancouver, BC without written consent of the other party or court order' | Patel-Singh: 'relocate the Children more than 75 kilometers from their current school without 60 days written notice and the other Party's consent or court order'

question_type_definitions.factual_extraction: Direct extraction of specific facts from the document
question_type_definitions.calculation: Questions requiring mathematical computation from document data
question_type_definitions.temporal_reasoning: Questions involving dates, durations, or time-based logic
question_type_definitions.legal_interpretation: Questions about the legal meaning or basis of provisions
question_type_definitions.legal_reasoning: Questions about the court's reasoning or legal analysis
question_type_definitions.legal_strategy: Questions about what relief or approach a party is seeking
question_type_definitions.multi_hop: Questions requiring synthesis of multiple pieces of information
question_type_definitions.cross_document: Questions requiring information from multiple documents
question_type_definitions.income_determination: Questions about how income is calculated for support
question_type_definitions.procedural: Questions about process or implementation of orders
question_type_definitions.urgent_relief: Questions about emergency or interim relief circumstances
